text: in this video you'll see how to create a
secure devops pipeline for aws service
catalog
with this solution you can leverage
reference architecture from github to
easily set up a continuous integration
and continuous delivery or cicd pipeline
that employs devops and infrastructure
as code or iac
practices we'll begin from the github
repository that contains the aws service
catalog reference architecture for the
cicd pipeline this diagram gives a quick
overview of the reference architecture
the service catalog reference
architecture portfolio contains
instructions and links for single
account and multi-account setups
for this example we'll deploy the
architecture for a single account setup
for demonstration purposes we have
already launched the stacks and set them
up in our aws account
let's take a look
the reference architecture created a
portfolio with the service catalog
products needed to deploy the pipeline
note that we'll be deploying the
pipeline alongside amazon elastic
compute cloud or amazon ec2
but any aws resources that can be
defined and provisioned through service
catalog products can be used with this
solution
the reference architecture also
provisioned two identity and access
management groups for service catalog
end users
in addition the portfolio includes an
aws cloud 9 integrated development
environment
or ide we can use to edit code and push
changes to the code commit repository
you can of course choose to configure
your local development environment for
this purpose
we'll retain the default instance
settings
next let's go to cloud formation and
find the git repository url in the code
pipeline stack outputs so we can
associate the repository with the
development environment
let's copy the url and then return to
the cloud9 provisioning wizard to paste
it in
let's also specify the base folder path
name for our git repository
the ec2 reference architecture requires
that we specify two tag values before we
can launch the product
now that the environment has been
provisioned let's view its outputs so we
can begin editing and deploying service
catalog product templates
here's the url for the cloud 9 ide
we are now in the cloud 9 environment
the git repository we specified in the
provisioning wizard is automatically
cloned to our current directory
but it is empty since we have yet to
push anything to it
let's copy the deployed templates from
the reference architecture repository to
the service catalog portfolios repo
folder associated with the pipeline
next let's look at the repository that
has been linked to our code pipeline
resource
since we'll be working in a single
account setup we need to make some minor
modifications to the build spec file so
that it executes successfully
let's uncomment the command to run
cloudformation updates
and comment out two lines relevant to a
multi-account setup
next let's add the template files to our
git repository and commit the changes
finally let's push the changes to the
git repository hosted on code commit
which was automatically deployed
alongside the code pipeline resource
this will trigger the code pipeline
execution
let's go to our pipeline to see the
execution taking place
the execution has begun indicating that
the git repository with our service
catalog
product templates is associated and
configured correctly
let's skip ahead to when all steps have
been executed
as you can see the pipeline has
successfully sourced all files from our
code commit git repository
validated and linted our template files
and deployed the templates to service
catalog
as products let's take a look at the
template validation steps build
execution details
the cfn nag linting tool looks for any
potential format or syntax errors in the
service catalog product templates before
they are deployed to end users
templates with errors won't be deployed
next let's look at the copy and deploy
step
this step deploys the validated service
catalog product template files to
service catalog
let's go to service catalog to see the
products from an end user's perspective
so far we haven't made any changes to
the product templates to demonstrate
that the pipeline is functioning
correctly
let's make a change to the nginx demo
web server
we'll restrict users from provisioning
these web servers with the t3
large instance type to do so let's
return to our development environment
let's open the json file that specifies
the ngenx demo web server service
catalog
product definition within our git
repository
we'll make a change to the product
version number
next let's open the json file
corresponding to this product's end user
provisioning parameters
we'll remove the t3 large option from
the list of allowed instance type values
now let's add commit and push our
changes to the git repository
which will again trigger the pipeline
execution
the pipeline has finished executing
let's return to the service catalog end
user view
and see if our changes are reflected in
the product
as expected the product version has been
updated to 1.1
let's provision an nginx web server
through service catalog to see the list
of available instance types
the t3 large instance type is not
available indicating that our change is
reflected and the pipeline is
functioning correctly
you've just seen how to create a secure
devops pipeline for aws service catalog
thanks for watching now it's your turn
to try
